reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s key heuristic in Sec. 2.4: that future value is (roughly) a product of many (roughly) independent factors, yielding a highly skewed distribution where “mostly-great” futures are rare. That’s important to the paper’s intuitive case for “no easy eutopia,” though the paper also offers other supports (e.g., the fussy/easygoing analysis in Sec. 3), so undermining the multiplicative-independence intuition wouldn’t fully collapse the overall position (hence centrality ~0.55). The critique is moderately strong: it correctly notes that assuming independence is doing substantive work in the toy model, and that positive correlations (a latent ‘governance competence’ variable) can substantially reduce the probability mass near zero compared to independent multiplicative factors. However, it overstates with “flip direction” and “makes easy eutopia more likely than your argument allows”: correlations can mitigate but need not reverse the conclusion; and the paper doesn’t claim empirical independence, only uses the model illustratively and also argues many of the “single flaw” risks may not be tightly coupled to general competence. Still, the core point (missing causal/empirical justification for near-independence, and sensitivity to correlation structure) is largely correct and clearly presented, with little extraneous material.
title: Correlated governance competence undermines the independence assumption driving multiplicative collapse
